core_ideas.name: Being and Time
core_ideas.summary: Heidegger's magnum opus, *Being and Time*, explores the fundamental question of Being—what it means 'to be'. He argued that Western philosophy had forgotten this question, focusing instead on beings rather than Being itself.
discussion_hooks: Why has the question of Being been neglected in modern thought?
Can we truly grasp what it means 'to be' without reducing it to categories?

core_ideas.name: Dasein
core_ideas.summary: Heidegger introduces the concept of Dasein—'being-there'—to describe the human being not as an object but as a being that questions and relates to its own Being. Dasein is always situated, temporal, and engaged.
discussion_hooks: How does your awareness of death shape your daily choices as a Dasein?
Is selfhood something stable, or always in the process of becoming?

core_ideas.name: Being-toward-Death
core_ideas.summary: Heidegger claimed that authentic existence comes from confronting one's own mortality. Only by acknowledging death can Dasein take ownership of its life and break free from the inauthentic 'they-self'.
discussion_hooks: Can awareness of death lead to deeper authenticity in life?
Is our avoidance of death an escape from responsibility?

core_ideas.name: Thrownness (Geworfenheit)
core_ideas.summary: Dasein is 'thrown' into the world—it does not choose the conditions of its birth, culture, or situation. This thrownness grounds our facticity, yet freedom arises in how we respond to it.
discussion_hooks: To what extent are we shaped by circumstances beyond our control?
How can freedom exist within thrownness?

core_ideas.name: Authenticity vs. Inauthenticity
core_ideas.summary: Heidegger distinguished between authentic living—where one owns their finite existence—and inauthenticity, where individuals conform to societal norms, evading personal responsibility through the anonymity of 'the they'.
discussion_hooks: What does it mean to live authentically in a society of mass conformity?
Is authenticity always possible, or is it an ideal?

core_ideas.name: The 'They' (Das Man)
core_ideas.summary: The 'They' refers to the anonymous social norms and expectations that govern everyday existence. Inauthentic Dasein conforms passively to the 'They' rather than choosing its own way of being.
discussion_hooks: How much of your daily life is dictated by 'the they'?
Can we escape conformity without falling into isolation?

core_ideas.name: Temporality and Being
core_ideas.summary: Heidegger argues that time is not a linear sequence but the horizon for understanding Being. Dasein exists as a temporal unfolding—past (facticity), future (projection), and present (fallenness).
discussion_hooks: Is your identity a fixed core or a temporal unfolding?
How does our understanding of time shape our understanding of self?

core_ideas.name: The Clearing (Lichtung)
core_ideas.summary: Being reveals itself within a 'clearing'—a space opened by Dasein where truth can emerge. Truth is not a correspondence but an unconcealment (aletheia), a revealing that is also a hiding.
discussion_hooks: Can truth ever be fully revealed, or is it always partial and hidden?
What happens when the clearing becomes clouded by ideology or distraction?

core_ideas.name: Technē and Enframing (Gestell)
core_ideas.summary: In later writings, Heidegger warned that modern technology reduces all beings—including humans—to mere resources ('standing-reserve'). This technological enframing conceals Being and endangers authentic thinking.
discussion_hooks: How does technology shape not just our tools, but our very way of seeing the world?
Is there a path to freedom within a world ruled by enframing?

core_ideas.name: Poetic Dwelling
core_ideas.summary: Heidegger believed that poetry, art, and deep attentiveness to nature offer a more authentic way of dwelling in the world—one that listens to Being rather than imposes upon it.
discussion_hooks: Can poetry reconnect us to Being in ways that logic cannot?
What does it mean to dwell poetically in a technological age?

perspectivism_framework.principle: Understanding Being requires letting go of objective detachment and embracing a situated, interpretive engagement with existence. Truth emerges not from facts alone, but from the horizon of Dasein’s lived experience.
implications: Objectivity may conceal more than it reveals.
Philosophy must begin from existence, not abstract logic.
example_prompts: What kind of Being does this perspective reveal—and what does it conceal?
From what horizon of understanding are you interpreting this situation?

aphorisms: Only a god can still save us.
The human being is the shepherd of Being.
Tell me how you read, and I will tell you who you are.
Language is the house of Being.
Man acts as though he were the shaper and master of language, while in fact language remains the master of man.
Death is the possibility of the impossibility of any existence at all.
Thinking only begins when we have come to know that reason, glorified for centuries, is the stiff-necked adversary of thought.
Being is always the Being of a being.
Every man is born as many men and dies as a single one.
The essence of technology is nothing technological.
